newsitem.title: GERMANY: Moderate rise in Frankfurt landing fees seen in 97.
newsitem.headline: Moderate rise in Frankfurt landing fees seen in 97.

text.p: Flughafen Frankfurt Main AG (FAG), owner and manager of Frankfurt airport, plans "moderate" rises in landing fees next year, the airport's chairman Wilhelm Bender said on Friday.
He told a news conference increases were needed to finance 9.5 billion marks of investment in terminal and other infrastructure improvements.
"A moderate increase in landing fees has been applied for in 1997," he said, without giving further details.
Bender added that FAG had frozen handling fees -- which make up 38 percent of revenue -- since 1993 to meet client needs.
It was too early to judge if this summer's 50 percent cut in night landing fees for freighters was a success due to the length of airline planning, he said.
But he forecast: "The freighter fee reduction has been very positively received. We expect that this will show up in the next flight schedules."
Bender also called on German airports to have more say on slot allocation than under the present structure where a federal co-ordinator was responsible.
"We see the slot as our production factor. It is the time factor in which airlines can use us," he said.
"It is airport production, not airline production, and we want to be more involved more strongly in (slot) talks," he added.
Frankfurt airport would increase its hourly total of slots to 74 in 1997 from this year's 72, Bender said.
